nodes.body: I ended up just pushing the two suggestions above
OK hopefully now everything is dealt with.

Modulo the last three comments,

bors d+

:v: al-ramsey can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7803767371/job/21284236696)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7803767371/job/21284236185)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7803767371/job/21284236936)

Should this be written using `*`? I think `mul` is an implementation detail.
```suggestion
  comul_mul : ∀ a₁ a₂ : A, comul (a₁ * a₂) = comul a₁ * comul a₂
```

I think this lemma can be dropped, along with the one below; `apply` seems unnecessary in the lemma name, and you can use `attribute [simp] Bialgebra.comul_mul` instead to avoid duplicating the statement
What about making `R` and `A` explicit here, so one can use `counitAlgHom R A` (similarly to `algebraMap R A`) without knowing the name of the instance?
Done!

```suggestion
import Mathlib.RingTheory.TensorProduct
```
It seems unlikely that this import is required here.

I thought so too -- but it's needed! For coalgebras we only need tensor products of R-modules; for bialgebras we need to claim that comultiplication is a ring homomorphism so we need tensor products of R-algebras.

I think it will turn out to be easier to make instances of this (especially for `TensorProduct` and `Finsupp`) if you use
```suggestion
  mul_compr₂_counit : (LinearMap.mul R A).compr₂ counit = (LinearMap.mul R R).compl₁₂ counit counit
```
and then prove a `counit_mul` lemma using `FunLike.congr_fun`. Similarly for `comul`.

I find this comment slightly hard to believe, but more to the point I made this change on the tube home and now I think that this makes the definition super-ugly and incomprehensible to a passing mathematician. Thus I propose instead leaving the definition alone (i.e. reverting the last two commits) and instead making a constructor with the incomprehensible fields instead (which you can use for tensor products or whatever). Would you be happy with this @eric-wieser ? I don't immediately see the advantage of making the definition itself obscure.

The arguments for changing the definition are:
* I claim that *every* `instance` of this typeclass will want to use my proposed constructor. Anyone who doesn't will be making more work for themselves, and if it's not the default constructor, these people may not even be aware that the "easy" constructor exists. Of course, docstrings can lessen this issue.
* Only the default constructor works with `where` notation
* The fields for `Coalgebra` are stated in this point-free way already (for the same reason), so this is in some sense consistent

I agree that this definition is unfriendly to a mathematician reading it, but so is `Group` and many other typeclasses in mathlib. I don't yet have a good answer to how to solve that problem. Maybe it's worth getting a second opinion from Zulip on this.

OK after consulting with someone else (who thinks you're right) I have gone with the obscure definition as the default, and added the less scary one as `Bialgebra.mk'`. Hopefully the docstrings are helpful if people are confused.

I think this should be written as
```suggestion
lemma comul_mul (a b : A) : comul (R := R) (a * b) = comul a * comul b :=
```
to avoid naming the instance

```suggestion
@[simps]
def counitAlgHom : A →ₐ[R] R where
```
also, can you add the trivial consequences of this morphism as simp lemmas, but about `counit`? Namely that `counit (algebraMap R A r) = r` and `counit (a ^ n) = counit a ^ n`, and similarly for comul?

```suggestion
  counit_one := counit_one
  mul_compr₂_counit := by ext; exact counit_mul
  comul_one := comul_one
  mul_compr₂_comul := by ext; exact comul_mul
```
Oops! Thanks!

```suggestion
  by `counit`. The second factors through `R ⊗[R] R`, and is `counit ⊗ counit` followed by
```

```suggestion
Authors: Ali Ramsey, Kevin Buzzard
```

```suggestion
  are the following: the first factors through `A` and is multiplication on `A` followed
```
Could there please be an explanation of why this is written in a rather obscure way? :-)
There's an explanation on this github page but you're right: I've added it to the module docstring as an implementation note.
No, I don't think so. Because of the way they are written, presumably they will never fire.
Missing the codomains: should be `A →ₗ[R] A →ₗ[R] R` and `A ⊗[R] A →ₗ[R] R`
Maybe remove the parentheses for consistency
